texts.shortText: Small, glossy greenish-black cormorant with relatively long tail, an obvious upright tuft of feathers on the head (hence common name). Eyes distinctively ruby-red. Bill shortish and black, lower mandible with yellow-orange base and gape orange. Bare pinkish skin above and in front of eyes swells and becomes red during courtship. Legs and feet black.
Total length 54 cm, wingspan 85 cm mass about 790 g in males, 730 g in females, sexes alike.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: West coast species, found from northern Namibia to Cape Agulhas.

Uncommon species with a restricted range and a total population of probably only about 2 500 pairs. Found only along the coast and seldom range inland or more than 10 km out to sea. Fairly resident and occur in small colonies on islands, piers and artificial platforms, often mixed with other cormorants.

Forages by pursuit-diving close inshore, usually singly and in water less than 5 m deep along rocky shore or in kelp beds, not along beaches. Usually undertake a bout of short dives of duration less than 1 min separated by intervals of a few seconds; then rests ashore, often with wings spread to warm body and aid digestion.
Feeds mainly on small benthic fish, such as klipfish, pipefish and blennies, but also takes crustaceans, molluscs including cephalopods, and polychaete worms.

Nests in small colonies of usually less than 30 pairs, often among colonies of other species. Usually on islands or other sites inaccessible to mammalian predators, such as cliffs, shipwrecks, piers, moored boats, etc. Nest a rough platform of sticks, seaweeds, feathers and bones. Eggs 1-5, pale bluish-white with chalky outer layer. Incubation period 22-23 days, chicks form creches at about 22 days and are independent after 45-60 days

Could be confused with Cape and Bank cormorants, but these are both larger with longer bills, and shorter tails. Both also lack both red eyes and prominent crest on head characteristic of crowned cormorant.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robertâ€™s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 573).
